key_points: Facebook and Google are criticized for failing to effectively combat scam ads on their platforms, even after they are reported by users.
Online fraud has seen a significant increase due to lockdowns keeping people indoors globally.
Both tech giants have faced pressure to address the issue, with accusations of Facebook having a lax approach.
A study by British consumer group Which? found that 34% of Google-reported scam ads were not removed, and 26% for Facebook-reported ads.
Scammers are creating fake ads using established brands' logos and branding to steal financial details from consumers.
Victims are more likely to come across fraudulent ads on Facebook than on Google.
Consumer rights expert, Adam French, urges UK government legislation to tackle the problem of online scams.
The proposed Online Safety Bill in the UK could impose fines on tech companies failing to remove 'harmful' content.
Facebook and Google spokespeople claim their companies proactively fight fraudulent activity and have removed scam ads.
Insider previously reported on scammers using fake quotes from celebrities to promote fraudulent cryptocurrency schemes on YouTube.
